action.action-desc: Mr. Burr (for himself and Mr. Franken) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

form.official-title: To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act with respect to devices.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the FDA Device Accountability Act of 2015.

section.header: Ensuring least burdensome means of evaluating devices

subsection.header: Training and oversight of least burdensome requirements
subsection.text: Section 513 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360c) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subsection.header: Training and oversight of least burdensome requirements

subparagraph.text: ensure that each employee of the Food and Drug Administration who is involved in the review of premarket submissions, including supervisors, receives training regarding the meaning and implementation of the least burdensome requirements under subsections (a)(3)(D) and (i)(1)(D) and section 515(c)(5); and

periodically assess the implementation of the least burdensome requirements, including the employee training under subparagraph (A) to ensure that the least burdensome requirements are fully and consistently applied.

paragraph.text: Not later than 180 calendar days after the date of enactment of the FDA Device Accountability Act of 2015, the ombudsman for any organizational unit of the Food and Drug Administration responsible for the premarket review of devices shall—

subparagraph.text: conduct an audit of the training described in paragraph (1)(A);

include in such audit interviews of persons who are representatives of the device industry regarding their experience in the device premarket review process, including with respect to the application of least burdensome concepts to premarket review and the application of postmarket requirements to facilitate premarket decisionmaking;

include in such audit an assessment of the measurement tools the Secretary uses to assess the implementation of the least burdensome requirements, including the effectiveness of such tools and the effectiveness of the implementation of the least burdensome requirements; and
within 30 calendar days of completion of the audit, make such audit available—

clause.text: to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions of the Senate and the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives; and
on the Internet website of the Food and Drug Administration.

subsection.text: Section 515(c) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360e(c)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: In requesting additional information with respect to an application under this section, the Secretary shall consider the least burdensome appropriate means necessary to demonstrate a reasonable assurance of device safety and effectiveness.

For purposes of subparagraph (A) the term necessary means the minimum required information that would support a determination by the Secretary that an application provides a reasonable assurance of the safety and effectiveness of the device.
Nothing in this paragraph alters the standards for premarket approval of a device.

For purposes of this paragraph, the Secretary shall consider whether the least burdensome means of demonstrating a reasonable assurance of device safety and effectiveness would be achieved through reliance on postmarket information.

subsection.header: Rationale for significant decisions regarding devices
subsection.text: Section 517A(a) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360g–1(a)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The substantive summary required under this subsection shall include an explanation of how the least burdensome requirements were considered and applied consistent with section 513(i)(1)(D) and section 513(a)(3)(D) and section 515(c)(5), as applicable.

subsection.text: Section 520 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360(j)) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by striking local each place it appears; and
in subparagraph (A)(i), by striking which has been; and
by striking local each place it appears; and
by amending subparagraph (A) to read as follows:
in facilities in which clinical testing of devices is supervised by an institutional review committee established in accordance with the regulations of the Secretary; and

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services shall revise or issue such regulations or guidance as may be necessary to carry out the amendments made by subsection (a).

section.header: Clarifying CLIA waiver study design guidance for in vitro diagnostics

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services shall publish a draft guidance that—

paragraph.text: revises section V. Demonstrating Insignificant Risk of an Erroneous Result – Accuracy of the guidance entitled Recommendations for Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA) Waiver Applications for Manufacturers of In Vitro Diagnostic Devices and dated January 30, 2008; and
includes guidance on the appropriate use of comparable performance between a waived user and a moderately complex laboratory user to demonstrate accuracy.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall finalize the draft guidance published under subsection (a) not later than 1 year after the comment period for such draft guidance closes.
